entry.title: Galaxy Version 19.01 Released
entry.content:
Galaxy 19.01 has now been released!
This release includes the revised UI style, addition of colorful tags, extensive workflow enhancements, and enhanced support for Singularity.

Please see the release notes for additional information.

Galaxy Australia will be moving to this Galaxy version in the upcoming weeks. More information will be forthcoming.
entry.summary: Galaxy 19.01 has now been released! This release includes the revised UI style, addition of colorful tags, extensive workflow enhancements, and enhanced support for Singularity.

entry.title: New tools added: Heatmaps and VSearch

link.title: New tools added: Heatmaps and VSearch

entry.content:
This week we have added a number of new tools to Galaxy Australia

New tools:

  • Heatmap w ggplot: This tool will generate a clustered heatmap of your data.
  • Heatmap2: Employs the heatmap.2 function from the R gplots package and will generate a heatmap of your data.
  • chimera.vsearch: Part of the Mothur suite - find potential chimeric sequences using vsearch

Updated tools:

  • VSearch suite: now at version 2.8.3.0
entry.summary: This week we have added a number of new tools to Galaxy Australia

entry.title: Tutorial of the Month: Prokka
entry.content:
The Galaxy Project Training Network’s tutorial of the month for January/February 2019 is “Annotation of Bacterial Genomes with Prokka” chosen by our own Simon Gladman.

Here is a link to the Galaxy blog post referencing it.
entry.summary: The Galaxy Project Training Network’s tutorial of the month for January/February 2019 is “Annotation of Bacterial Genomes with Prokka” chosen by our own Simon Gladman.

entry.title: Galaxy Server Maintenance
entry.content:
Galaxy Australia will be undergoing maintenance for 2 hours on the 20th February 2019 from 10:00am AEDT. It will be getting:

  • a new landing page
  • the tool panel will be updated to match usegalaxy.org and usegalaxy.eu
  • the backend will be upgraded to fix some job running issues

We thank you for your patience in advance.
entry.summary: Galaxy Australia will be undergoing maintenance for 2 hours on the 20th February 2019 from 10:00am AEDT. It will be getting: a new landing page the tool panel will be updated to match usegalaxy.org and usegalaxy.eu the backend will be upgraded to fix some job running issues

entry.title: Summer Holiday Support
entry.content: Galaxy Australia will be minimally administered during the university shutdown period from 24th December 2019 to the 2nd January 2019. During this time, only essential maintenance will be performed. No disk quota modifications, tool installations or reference data installation or upgrades will be performed.
entry.summary: Galaxy Australia will be minimally administered during the university shutdown period from 24th December 2019 to the 2nd January 2019. During this time, only essential maintenance will be performed. No disk quota modifications, tool installations or reference data installation or upgrades will be performed.

entry.title: New Tools Added: Gemini Tools
entry.content: We have added the Gemini Tools to Galaxy Australia. These tools are for doing integrative exploration of genetic variation and genome annotations. The documentation for these tools can be found here. You can find these tools under the Gemini Tools section of the Galaxy Australia tool menu.
entry.summary: We have added the Gemini Tools to Galaxy Australia. These tools are for doing integrative exploration of genetic variation and genome annotations. The documentation for these tools can be found here. You can find these tools under the Gemini Tools section of the Galaxy Australia tool menu.

entry.title: Nominate a training for the 2019 Galaxy Community Conference (GCC2019)

link.title: Nominate a training for the 2019 Galaxy Community Conference (GCC2019)

entry.content: The 2019 Galaxy Community Conference (GCC2019) will be held in be held in Freiburg, Germany, 1-6 July. The training topics that are offered are determined by the community so BY YOU!
entry.summary: The 2019 Galaxy Community Conference (GCC2019) will be held in be held in Freiburg, Germany, 1-6 July. The training topics that are offered are determined by the community so BY YOU!

entry.title: Automatic workflow testing
entry.content:
We have started to test a few of our workflows automatically against UseGalaxy.eu. This will run all workflows monthly to ensure that the keep working and that our infrastructure works and scales well.

Feel free to contribute workflows to our testing repository or propose us workflows via opening an issue. Alternatively you can write us at contact@usegalaxy.eu. If you would like us to test these workflows on your server, just get in contact with us and we can do that as well.
entry.summary: We have started to test a few of our workflows automatically against UseGalaxy.eu. This will run all workflows monthly to ensure that the keep working and that our infrastructure works and scales well.

entry.title: Tutorial of the Month: “Reference-based RNA-Seq data analysis”, selected by Saskia Hiltemann

link.title: Tutorial of the Month: "Reference-based RNA-Seq data analysis", selected by Saskia Hiltemann

entry.content: The Galaxy community is developing and maintaining a collection of tutorials that are designed to be interactive and are built around Galaxy: https://training.galaxyproject.org. To help highlight our tutorials and the training effort of the community, a member of the community will select every month one tutorial and explains in the Galactic Blog why they select this tutorial. This month, the Galaxy contributor of the Month!, Saskia Hilteman, selects and presents a tutorial: “Reference-based RNA-Seq data analysis”, from the topic “Transcriptomics”
entry.summary: The Galaxy community is developing and maintaining a collection of tutorials that are designed to be interactive and are built around Galaxy: https://training.galaxyproject.org. To help highlight our tutorials and the training effort of the community, a member of the community will select every month one tutorial and explains in the Galactic Blog why they select this tutorial. This month, the Galaxy contributor of the Month!, Saskia Hilteman, selects and presents a tutorial: “Reference-based RNA-Seq data analysis”, from the topic “Transcriptomics”

entry.title: Initial release of `gxadmin` tool
entry.content:
The good folks over at Galaxy Europe have developed a cool bit of code to help out Galaxy systems administrators. It’s called gxadmin, it’s available on GitHub and includes many small SQL queries that administrators run every day.

As a Galaxy administrator, you can use it to do things like viewing the queue:

$ gxadmin query queue
                            tool_id                                |  state  | count
-------------------------------------------------------------------+---------+-------
 toolshed.g2.bx.psu.edu/repos/iuc/unicycler/unicycler/0.4.6.0      | queued  |     9
 toolshed.g2.bx.psu.edu/repos/iuc/dexseq/dexseq_count/1.24.0.0     | running |     7
 toolshed.g2.bx.psu.edu/repos/nml/spades/spades/1.2                | queued  |     6
 ebi_sra_main                                                      | running |     6
 toolshed.g2.bx.psu.edu/repos/iuc/trinity/trinity/2.8.3            | queued  |     5

amongst many more queries. We hope that other administrators will find this utility useful and can contribute queries that they run often.
entry.summary: The good folks over at Galaxy Europe have developed a cool bit of code to help out Galaxy systems administrators. It’s called gxadmin, it’s available on GitHub and includes many small SQL queries that administrators run every day.
